title: Integration with the FossilSim and paleotree packages
text: admtools can transform phylogenetic trees coded phylo objects well fossils taxonomy objects defined FossilSim package. allows transform phylogenetic trees associated taxonomic information fossil locations time stratigraphic domain. give example workflow
code: set.seed(42) # construct age-depth model my_adm = tp_to_adm(t = CarboCATLite_data$time_myr,                   h = CarboCATLite_data$height_2_km_offshore_m,                   L_unit = "m",                   T_unit = "Myr") # simulate phylogenetic tree t = ape::rbdtree(birth = 3, death = 1, Tmax = 2) # simulate taxonomy along the tree s = FossilSim::sim.taxonomy(tree = t) # simulate fossils based on taxonomy f = FossilSim::sim.fossils.poisson(rate = 4, taxonomy = s) # plot tree with taxonomy and fossil times FossilSim:::plot.fossils(f, tree = t, taxonomy = s, show.taxonomy = TRUE) ## transform everything into the strat domain t_strat = time_to_strat(t, my_adm) s_strat = time_to_strat(s, my_adm, destructive = FALSE) f_strat = time_to_strat(f, my_adm, destructive = FALSE) FossilSim:::plot.fossils(f_strat, tree = t_strat, taxonomy = s_strat, show.taxonomy = TRUE)

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Sedimentation Rates
text: t_tp h_tp must return strictly ordered numeric vectors times/heights. means users responsibility avoid inversions times/heights. example, assume stratigraphic positions tie points known without uncertainty, 10 20 m stratigraphic height. h_tp implemented follows: evaluated, function returns stratigraphic positions tie points: Note h_tp defined synonym h_tp = tp_height_det(c(h_min, h_max)). complex example, assume timing first tie point follows normal distribution mean 0 standard deviation 0.5. second tie point, maximum minimum time available. Due lack information, assume uniform distribution minimum (9) maximum (11). implemented follows t_tp: Using Myr time unit, distribution times tie points follows:
code: h_min = 10 # stratigraphic height of lower tie point [m] h_max = 20 # stratigraphic height of upper tie point [m] h_tp = function(){   return(c(h_min, h_max)) } h_tp() #> [1] 10 20 t_tp = function() {   repeat{      # timing first tie point     t1 = rnorm(n = 1, mean = 0, sd = 0.5)     # timing second tie point     t2 = runif(n = 1, min = 9, max = 11)     if (t1 < t2){ # if order is correct, return values         return(c(t1, t2))     }   } } t_tp() # evaluating the function returns a random pair of times drawn from the specified distribution #> [1]  0.2729596 10.6250840

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Sedimentation Rates

Computationally, implemented using function factories, functions return functions. function factory defines stochastic process, function ff generated function factory sample path. turn, f(x)f(x) returns value sample path xx . , function factories used complex random number generators: Instead returning one multiple random numbers, return random function.

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Sedimentation Rates
text: Available wrappers define sedimentation rates sed_rate_gen_from_bounds : generate sed. rate upper lower bounds sedimentation rate (see ) sed_rate_from_matrix: specify sedimentation rate based matrix, used conjunction get_data_from_eTimeOpt. allows sedimentation rates change deterministic randomized heights, see ?sed_rate_from_matrix details. sed_rate_gen_gamma : generate sed. rate based gamma distribution.

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Sedimentation Rates
text: Sedimentation rates must coded function factories, .e., functions return functions. must able take vector inputs return vector length output, always return strictly positive values. example, use simple sedimentation rate model, upper lower bounds sedimentation rates section known. limits, assume uniform distribution. Based parameters, sedimentation rate function factory defined follows: Note inner function function one variable (height), outer function takes arguments - simply returns inner function. visualize , let’s plot three sedimentation rates generated “sedimentation rate function factory” sed_rate_fun:  sedimentation rates generated sed_rate_fun different, determined random numbers.
code: h_min = 10 h_max = 90 # limits on sed. rates  lower_limit = c(0.1,2,0.1,10)  upper_limit = c(0.2,3,2,12)   # strat intervals where sed rates are defined  s = c(h_min, 30,65, 80, h_max) # define function factory  sed_rate_fun = function(){      # draw sed rates from uniform distribution     aa = runif(n = length(lower_limit), min = lower_limit, max = upper_limit)      # define sed rate "realization" based on samples from uniform distribution    sed_rate_fun = approxfun(x = s,                             y = c(aa, aa[length(aa)]),                             method = "constant",                             rule = 2,                             f = 1)    return(sed_rate_fun) } plot(NULL,      xlim = c(h_min, h_max),      ylim = c(0, max(upper_limit)),      xlab = "Stratigraphic Height [m]",      ylab = "Sedimentation Rate")  no_of_sedrates = 3 # no. of sed rates displayed h = seq(h_min,h_max, by = 0.1) # strat. positions where sed rates are plotted cols = c("red", "blue", "black") for (i in seq_len(no_of_sedrates)){   # generate sed rate from the factory   sed_rate_sample = sed_rate_fun()      # plot sed rate in the section   lines(h, sed_rate_sample(h), col = cols[i]) }

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Tracer Contents of Rocks and Sediments
text: stratigraphic contents time contents must coded function factories, .e., functions return functions. must able take vector inputs return vector length output, always return strictly positive values. example, assume tracer input sediment constant time. implemented following function: Note inner function function x (time), outer function takes arguments - simply returns inner function. visualize , let’s plot time 0 10:  lot effort code constant function. used approach shows power versatility used complex situations. example, assume tracer measured bottom, middle, top examined section: locations, tracer values measured follow normal distribution mean 10, 1, 8 standard deviations 1, 0.1, 0.2. assume measured points, tracer values change linearly. assumptions values, function factory tracer can coded follows visualize , 3 possible scenarios tracer values change section:
code: time_cont_gen = function(){   time_cont = function(x) return( rep(1, length(x)))   return(time_cont) } # generate one function from time_cont_gen time_cont = time_cont_gen() # time where to evaluate the function t = seq(0,10,by = 0.1) plot(x = t,      y = time_cont(t),      type = "l",      xlab = "Time [Myr]",      ylab = "Tracer Input into the Sediment [X/Myr]") h_min = 2 h_max = 5 locations = c( h_min,  mean(c(h_min, h_max)),  h_max) mean_vals = c(10,  1,  8) sd_vals = c( 1, 0.1, 0.8) strat_cont_gen = function(){   # draw sample tracer values from specified distributions    trac_vals = rnorm(n = length(mean_vals),                      mean = mean_vals,                      sd = sd_vals)    # define function that linearly interpolates between drawn values    strat_cont = approxfun(x = locations,                           y = trac_vals,                           yleft = trac_vals[1],                           yright = trac_vals[3])    return(strat_cont) } n = 3 # number of sampled tracer values  h = seq(h_min, h_max, by = 0.1) # determine tracer values every 0.1 m  plot(NULL,      xlim = c(h_min, h_max),      ylim = c(0, max(mean_vals) +2 * max(sd_vals)),      xlab = "Stratigraphic Height [m]",      ylab = "Measured Tracer [1/m]") cols = c("red", "blue", "black") for (i in seq_len(n)){   strat_cont = strat_cont_gen() # draw sample path from stoch process    # draw sample path   lines(x = h,         y = strat_cont(h),         col = cols[i]) }

title: Plotting Age-Depth Models
text: example, use age-depth model taken 4 km offshore carbonate platform modeled using CarboCAT Lite (Burgess 2013, 2023). data provided package. adm can directly plotted using standard plot command R. can modified using arguments listed ?plot.adm  prefixes lwd, lty, col stand line width, line type, color respectively. suffix destr destructive intervals, suffix acc intervals sediment accumulation.
code: adm = tp_to_adm(t = CarboCATLite_data$time_myr,                 h = CarboCATLite_data$height_4_km_offshore_m,                 L_unit = "m",                 T_unit = "Myr") plot(adm,      lwd_destr = 1,      lty_destr = 4,      col_destr = "blue",      lwd_acc = 1,      lty_acc = 1,      col_acc = "black")

title: admtools: Getting Started
text: admtools package defines three main classes: adm, sac multiadm. class adm represent single age-depth model, information can extracted (e.g. completeness, number hiatuses, etc.) can used transform data stratigraphic domain time domain. multiamd class list adm objects. multiadm objects used represent uncertainties age-depth models. Objects type sac sediment accumulation curves can contain information erosion, can turned age-depth models.

title: admtools: Getting Started
text: contrast name, admtools package currently deals time height instead age depth. sense, age-depth models time-height models. time height can negative values. handle ages, use time present. handle depths, use height point reference (e.g., sediment surface).

title: admtools: Getting Started
text: standard constructor age-depth models tp_to_adm (“tie point age-depth model”). returns objecto class adm. object combines information stratigraphic heights times erosive interval. allows transform data stratigraphic time domain, identify data destroyed due hiatuses. example, use timing stratigraphic positions tie points taken CarboCAT Lite construct age-depth model, use option directly associate length time units . age-depth model represents relationship elapsed model time accumulated sediment 2 km offshore synthetic carbonate platform.

title: admtools: Getting Started
text: Typing name my_adm console tell generated variable age-depth model get quick overview properties my_adm, use summary: want inspect insides object, use str: can manually manipulate fields adm object treating like list. recommend , might result unexpected downstream behavior. want extract tie points use get_L_tp get_T_tp. can plot adm objects via standard plot function. , use option highlight hiatuses red, increase linw width conservative ( = non-destructive) intervals.  can also plot sedimentation rates time domain using plot_sed_rate_t“:  information extraction sedimentation rates time domain see functions sed_rate_t sed_rate_t_fun. title: admtools: Getting Started
text: Use functions get_total_duration, get_total_thickness, get_completeness, get_hiat_no extract information: detailed information, can use get_hiat_duration get vector hiatus durations get_hiat_list get list hiatus positions duration. example, plot histogram hiatus durations, use  function is_destructive can used examine whether points time coincide hiatuses:
code: get_total_duration(my_adm) #total time covered by the age-depth model #> [1] 2 get_total_thickness(my_adm) # total thickness of section represented by the adm #> [1] 146.0621 get_completeness(my_adm) # stratigraphic completeness as proportion #> [1] 0.3265 get_incompleteness(my_adm) # stratigraphic incompleteness (= 1- strat. incompleteness) #> [1] 0.6735 get_hiat_no(my_adm) # number of hiatuses #> [1] 10 hist(x = get_hiat_duration(my_adm),      freq = TRUE,      xlab = "Hiatus duration [Myr]",      main = "Hiatus duration 2 km offshore") is_destructive(my_adm,                t = c(0.1,0.5))  #> [1] FALSE  TRUE

previous_headings: Introduction > Extracting data from age-depth models > Transforming data between time and stratigraphic domain
title: admtools: Getting Started
text: functions get_height get_time workhorses transform data using age-depth models. get_time takes adm object vector heights h (stratigraphic positions), returns vector times get_height takes adm object vector times t returns vector associated stratigraphic positions example, say want know time deposition following stratigraphic positions: Conversely, determine parts section deposited specific time, use , NA indicates time 1.4 coincides erosion. want know stratigraphic position hiatus coincides time, use option destructive = FALSE: Alternatively, can also use wrappers strat_to_time time_to_strat transformation. expanded modeling features please use StratPal package (Github | Webpage | CRAN). provides biological context utility functions build modeling pipelines include ecological, taphonomic, stratigraphic, evolutionary effects.
code: h = c(30,120) # stratigraphic positions get_time(my_adm,          h = h) #> [1] 0.1380552 1.2704696 t = c(0.2,1.4) get_height(my_adm,            t = t) #> [1] 39.13951       NA t = c(0.2,1.4) get_height(my_adm,            t = t,            destructive = FALSE) #> [1]  39.13951 126.27764

title: admtools: Getting Started
text: admtools package can transform complex objects time stratigraphic domain. done using functions strat_to_time time_to_strat. example, transform chronogram (phylogenetic tree branch length represents time). example tree following birth-death model stored package variable timetree. See ?timetree details tree generated.  can transform tree using time_to_strat: Plotting resulting tree along stratigraphic column shows evolutionary relationships preserved 2 km offshore simulated carbonate platform:
code: #install.packages("ape") Package for analyses of phylogenetics and evolution # see ?ape::rlineage for help #set.seed(1)  ape::plot.phylo(timetree) # see also ?ape::plot.phylo axis(1) mtext("Time [Myr]", side = 1, line = 2.5) tree_in_strat_domain = time_to_strat(obj = timetree,                                      x = my_adm) ape::plot.phylo(tree_in_strat_domain, direction = "upwards") axis(side = 2) mtext("Stratigraphic Height [m]",       side = 2,       line = 2)

previous_headings: Introduction > Extracting data from age-depth models > Transforming data between time and stratigraphic domain
title: admtools: Getting Started
text: admtools can transform lists time height domain vice versa given elements names h t. lists can interpreted time/stratigraphic series, times stratigraphic positions associated measured values. Note ts objects used stats package, generally heterodistant due irregular nature age-depth transformation. example, simulate trait evolution 2 Myr using Brownian motion, transform simulation stratigraphic domain.   Note jump traits generated erosional interval my_adm. time_to_strat strat_to_time return stratlist timelist objects applied lists. like ordinary lists, come simplified plotting optionality, see ?plot.stratlist ?plot.timelist details. expanded modeling features biological context, please use StratPal package (Github | Webpage | CRAN). provides light wrappers around admtools box modeling trait evolution.
code: t = seq(0, 2, by = 0.001) # times BM = function(t){   #" Simulate Brownian motion at times t   li = list("t" = t,             "y" = cumsum(c(0, rnorm(n = length(t) - 1, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(diff(t))))))   class(li) = c("timelist", "list") # assign class `timelist` for easy plotting, see ?plot.timelist   return(li) } evo_list = BM(t) plot(x = evo_list,      xlab = "Time [Myr]",      ylab = "Trait Value",      type = "l") strat_list = time_to_strat(obj = evo_list,                             x = my_adm) plot(x = strat_list,      orientation = "lr",      type = "l",      xlab = "Stratigraphic Height [m]",      ylab = "Trait Value",      main = "Trait Evolution 2 km Offshore")

previous_headings: Introduction > S3 Classes > S3 class adm
title: Structure and classes of the admtools package
text: S3 class adm represents age depth models. Structurally, lists five fields: t : numeric vector, time points h : numeric vectors, heights destr: logical vector, interval destructive T_unit : NULL string, time unit L_unit : NULL string, length unit h[] height time t[]. h t must length least 2 elements, t must strictly increasing h must nondecreasing. length(destr) must identical length(t) - 1. destr[] == TRUE indicates time interval t[] t[+1] destructive information preserved. Whether tie points considered destructive determined function is_destructive. Geologically, destr[] == TRUE imply h[] == h[+1] , sediment accumulated hiatuses.

title: Depth-depth curves and correlation
text: admtools comes utilities deal depth-depth curves used correlation sections. See developer documentation (vignette("admtools_doc")) available functionality.

title: Depth-depth curves and correlation
text: two ways construct depth-depth curves: coeval tie points age-depth models. construct depth-depth curves coeval tie points use tp_to_ddc (ddc stands depth-depth curve). Alternatively, can use two age-depth models construct depth-depth curves via adm_to_ddc. construct depth-depth curves overlapping time interval.
code: # simulation data # entries in vectors are coeval bc simulation time steps were identical h1 = CarboCATLite_data$height_2_km_offshore_m h2 = CarboCATLite_data$height_12_km_offshore_m ddc1 = tp_to_ddc(h1 = h1,                  h2 = h2,                  L_unit_1 = "m", # associate length units                  L_unit_2 = "m",                  sec_1 = "2 km offshore", # name of correlated sections                  sec_2 = "12 km offshore") adm_2km = tp_to_adm(t = CarboCATLite_data$time_myr,                     h = CarboCATLite_data$height_2_km_offshore_m,                     L_unit = "m",                     T_unit = "Myr")  adm_8km = tp_to_adm(t = CarboCATLite_data$time_myr,                     h = CarboCATLite_data$height_8_km_offshore_m,                     L_unit = "m",                     T_unit = "Myr")  ddc2 = adm_to_ddc(adm1 = adm_2km, adm2 = adm_8km) # assign section names ddc2 = set_section_names(ddc2, sec_names = c("2 km from shore", "8 km from shore"))

title: Depth-depth curves and correlation
text: can quickly plot depth-depth curves using plot:  quick overview contents provided via summary:
code: plot(ddc1,      type = "l",      xlab = "",      ylab = "") mtext(get_section_names(ddc1)[1], side = 1, line = 3) mtext(get_section_names(ddc1)[2], side = 2, line = 3) summary(ddc1) ## depth-depth curve between 2 km offshore and 12 km offshore  ## Thickness of 2 km offshore : 146.0621 m  ## Thickness of 12 km offshore : 16.51814 m

title: Depth-depth curves and correlation
text: Length units section names can extracted modified using get_L_units, set_L_units, get_section_names set_section_names. reverse direction correlation, use flip_ddc:   Note effectively flips plot along diagonal.
code: plot(ddc1, type = "l", xlab = "", ylab = "") # correlation from 2 km offshore to 12 km offshore mtext(get_section_names(ddc1)[1], side = 1, line = 3) mtext(get_section_names(ddc1)[2], side = 2, line = 3) ddc3 = flip_ddc(ddc1) plot(ddc3, type = "l", xlab = "", ylab = "") # correlates 12 km offshore with 2 km offshore mtext(get_section_names(ddc3)[1], side = 1, line = 3) mtext(get_section_names(ddc3)[2], side = 2, line = 3)
